isis.stitle: Electrical System Troubleshooting Guide - BE 200, CE 200, CE 300 Model - LIGHT SYSTEMS - Red And Amber Pupil Warning Lights - Stop Arm Outputs From ESC

svcsubproc.title: Fault Detection Management

note.para: The testing method for troubleshooting the electrical systems portrayed in this manual is a basic voltage test. An alternative method of checking for voltage drops within a given circuit may be a quicker method of identifying an exact problem.
The virtual fuse in the ESC will trip during a short. To reset the fuse, the key switch must be cycled.

svcsubproc.para: A fault in the stop arm will be apparent when the red pupil warning lights are activated and the stop arm does not extend. The ESC will also log a diagnostic trouble code (DTC) when there is a short in stop arm. Problems in the stop arm circuits can be caused by burned out lamps, a short, an open, or a problem in the ESC.

svcsubproc.title: Extended Description
svcsubproc.para: When the ESC is commanded to turn the red pupil warning lights on, the ESC will provide a ground signal on connector 1601 pin A. This will allow the stop arm relay to energize with voltage from fuse #22. Voltage from fuse #22 will also be applied to the front stop arm connector (J34A) pins 1 and 4 and to the rear stop arm connector (J139) pins 1 and 2. This will power the stop arm motors extending the stop arms.
Ground is supplied to the stop arm motors from the ground stud on the flasher plate.
